values.text: COVID-19 causes a respiratory illness manifested by fever, cough and difficulty breathing. Those three symptoms together are indications of COVID-19. However, COVID-19 infection can also produce symptoms similar to the flu like aches and pains, sore throat, runny nose, nasal congestion or diarrhea.

The City urges people to avoid going to urgent care or emergency rooms for COVID-19 testing or non-emergency needs to avoid overwhelming the health system or the emergency response system. Avoid the risk of spreading the virus at clinics and hospitals by using telehealth virtual visits or calling your health provider. Your physician will determine if there is another plausible diagnosis with similar symptoms (i.e. influenza). More information can be found at: Austin COVID-19 Information

As part of the coordinated public health response to COVID-19, the Austin-Travis County Emergency Operations Center recently established a social services branch, which includes multiple strike teams and task forces that focus on efforts including homelessness, food access and behavioral health, among others. View news release here.

generic.title: Choose the type of service you would like to know more about:

values.text: Austin Public Library’s Virtual Library provides all-ages access to eBooks, audiobooks, eLearning, entertainment, magazines and newspapers, homework help, and research and databases. - eBooks & eAudiobooks - eLearning - Entertainment - Magazines & Newspapers - Research & Databases Take advantage of the library’s digital offerings with an Austin Public Library card. This card provides access to the library’s digital materials and can be acquired without visiting a library location. The card is free for City of Austin residents and employees, or $22 for non-residents.

The following agencies provide Rapid Rehousing, Permanent Supportive Housing or other permanent housing programs: ●Caritas of Austin - Housing Programs ●Casa Marianella ●Downtown Austin Community Court ●Family Eldercare ●Foundation Communities ●Foundation for the Homeless ●Front Steps ●Integral Care ●Best Single Source Plus ●LifeWorks ●Saint Louise House ●Salvation Army- Downtown Shelter and Social Service Center

Here are some options that can help you with internet access: Charter is offering free Spectrum for 60 days to households with K-12 and/or college students who do not already have a Spectrum broadband subscription at any service level up to 100 Mbps. To enroll call 1-844-488-8395. Installation fees will be waived for new student households. AT&T is offering Internet access for limited income households for $10/month through the Access from AT&T Program. Eligibility has been expanded to households participating in the National School Lunch Program and Head Start.

Given the unprecedented situation, we understand most households will be generating extra trash and we want to make these uncertain times easier for all. Trash is collected curbside every week and we have waived all extra trash fees until further notice. Learn more about trash pick-up
For your health and safety, If your utilities have been disconnected, we can help you. Learn more

dialog_nodes.title: Watch a Video from the  World Health Organization (WHO)

values.text: Watch this video from the World Health Organization to learn what we know about COVID-19 right now.
Based on the symptoms you describe, you may just have seasonal allergies. Other allergy symptoms include sneezing and runny nose.

Common symptoms can vary from person to person. This information is intended to provide personal guidance. Only your doctor can make a complete diagnosis. Seek immediate medical attention for any serious or life threatening health issue.
Influenza (also known as “flu”) is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It can cause mild to severe illness, and at times can lead to death.

Flu signs and symptoms usually come on suddenly. People who are sick with flu often feel some or all of these symptoms:
•	Fever* or feeling feverish/chills
•	Cough
•	Sore throat
•	Runny or stuffy nose
•	Muscle or body aches
•	Headaches
•	Fatigue (tiredness)
•	Some people may have vomiting and diarrhea, though this is more common in children than adults.

The symptoms of flu can include fever or feeling feverish/chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches and fatigue (tiredness). Cold symptoms are usually milder than the symptoms of flu. People with colds are more likely to have a runny or stuffy nose. Colds generally do not result in serious health problems.

The City of Austin and Travis County have issued a Public Health Order requiring individuals to remain in place at home, with exceptions for essential work and activities. 

You can go on a walk, get exercise, or take a pet outside to go to the bathroom, as long as you maintain at least 6 feet of distance from others.
Learn more about the Stay at Home Order

For the state lab testing center, individuals will be contacted directly with their results within 72 hours, depending on test volume. Do not call the state lab, the state health department, or a local public health agency to get your results. Otherwise, the person who requests the tests will receive the results. If your doctor submitted your test to the lab, your doctor will receive your results and communicate those results to you.

There are a lot of unknowns in the world right now. But one thing is certain, your emotional needs are important and if you are worried or upset, there is help. You may be feeling anxiety and worry, sleeping troubles, over or under eating, or sadness and depressed mood. If you have any of these symptoms, please reach out to:
  • Integral Care 24-Hour Crisis Hotline: 512-472-HELP (4357)
  • National Alliance for Mental Illness Helpline: 1-800-950-NAMI (6264) or text NAMI to 741741 from Monday-Friday 10:00 a.m.-6:00 p.m. ET
  • National Suicide Prevention Lifeline : 1-800-273-8255

dialog_nodes.title: What Can You Help Me With

values.text: I can help answer a variety of questions you may have around the Covid-19 outbreak, such as what are the symptoms of the virus, how to get tested, and when to expect your test results. I can provide guidance from your state and the CDC on school closures, large events, and travel. I can also give tips on how you can prevent the virus from spreading and how to disinfect your home . And more! How can I help you?
You can go for a walk, get exercise, or take your pet outside to go to the bathroom, as long as at least six feet of social distance is maintained with others. Learn more: Contain the Spread

The Economic Development Department is offering services for businesses who may find themselves struggling in the coming weeks. They include free business coaching, emergency planning resources, and a Family Business Loan Program.
Learn more about Small Business Opportunities

options.label: What to do if you are sick
Steps to help prevent the spread of COVID-19

values.text: Seasonal allergies cause sneezing, coughing, runny nose and irritated skin or eyes while COVID-19 can be mild but can include fever, body aches and difficulty breathing. COVID-19 or the flu come on quickly while allergies are mitigated by limiting exposure (not going outside).

The decision to hold or cancel an event rests with the organizer of that event, just as the decision to attend an event or mass gathering rests with each individual. Event cancellations is an evolving situation. For more guidance, you can also visit the CDC website.

dialog_nodes.title: How do I wash my hands?

values.text: This video answers important questions about hand washing and hand sanitizer.

Based on the symptoms you describe, you may just have the flu. Other flu symptoms include coughing, fatigue, weakness, and exhaustion.

Common symptoms can vary from person to person. This information is intended to provide personal guidance. Only your doctor can make a complete diagnosis. Seek immediate medical attention for any serious or life threatening health issue.

While you can certainly call your primary physician for advice and guidance the nominal cold will not require a doctor visit unless secondary indications require a visit – for example, if you contract a sinus infection or begin to have more severe breathing issues or lung and chest pains. Because the common cold is a virus, antibiotics won’t help. But over-the-counter medications may make you feel better.
The CDC considers a person to have a fever when he or she has a measured temperature of 100.4° F (38° C) or greater, or feels warm to the touch, or gives a history of feeling feverish.
I'm sorry. I am unable to help you until you have agreed to our terms.

The City of Austin defines social distancing as remaining and managing a minimum of six feet of separation between people other than during incidental and momentary passing.

Social distancing is not social isolation. Physical distancing is a critical part of preventing the spread of COVID-19.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines social distancing as a strategy used to help prevent a widespread influenza pandemic. Global efforts to combat this influenza pandemic will rely on both pharmaceutical and non-pharmaceutical interventions. Community infection control measures comprise a variety of non-pharmaceutical strategies designed to limit the transmission of pandemic influenza. These measures work by reducing the opportunity for people to come in contact with infected persons and thus for the virus to spread, reducing the total number of persons affected.

Childcare facilities that provide services to essential employees, such as healthcare workers are not impacted by the Stay Home-Work Safe Order.  

Childcare or daycare facilities must make sure they are following the social distancing requirements.  

Childcare must be carried out in stable groups of 10 or fewer (“stable” means that the same 10 or fewer children are in the same group each day).  

Children shall not change from one group to another. If more than one group of children is cared for at one facility, each group shall be in a separate room.  

Groups shall not mix with each other. Childcare providers shall remain with the same group of children.

These Parks and Recreation Department facilities are closed to the public starting Monday, March 16th: ● All recreation centers ● All cultural centers ● All museums ● All senior centers ● All aquatic facilities (includes all pools and splash pads) ● All golf courses ● All tennis centers ● All playgrounds ● Zilker Botanical Garden ● Zilker Caretaker House ● Old Bakery & Emporium ● All special event facilities ● Emma Long Metropolitan Park campsites However, most City of Austin parks and trails remain open. Just practice physical distancing of 6 feet or more when you visit. . Learn more about parks, pools, and trails closures.

Restaurants' common dining areas and bars will be closed from Tuesday, March 17 until May 1, 2020 unless changed under New Orders, also known as the Stay Home - Work Safe order, designed to slow the spread of COVID-19. Read the full Stay Home - Work Safe order (PDF, 2.4 MB) and learn more about essential activities and businesses under the order.
If you are a healthcare provider, the City has a great collection of resources for you. Please learn more here: Link
Click here to access a resource for your patients that are deaf or hard of hearing: Link
Please contact your local grocery store to learn what items are available.

In-person cashier services are suspended until the March 24, 2020, Order is lifted. Payment is available online through the Austin Build + Connect online portal (AB+C). Online payment options include E-check, credit card and escrow. If you have questions, please email us: permitsubmittal\@austintexas.gov
Please email dsddac\@austintexas.gov or use the Austin Build + Connect Online portal(AB+C) for information about obtaining an Alcoholic Beverage License Zoning Verification .

Staff are teleworking and are available from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday via  fiscalsurety\@austintexas.gov to answer any questions, and provide instructions for submitting your fiscal deposit digitally.

generic.title: Here are some of the most up-to-date bulletins from the CDC:

options.label: Watch this video to learn about COVID-19
Facts About COVID-19 from the CDC

values.text:
Seasonal allergies, also known as allergic rhinitis or hay fever, are an immune response to pollen and mold. Unlike a cold or the flu, allergy symptoms often last for several weeks to months of the years.  Allergies can also be an underlying cause of frequent sinus, ear, and respiratory infections. Symptoms include:
•	Sinus Congestion
•	Runny Nose
•	Post-Nasal Drip
•	Sneezing
•	Coughing
•	Itchy or Watery Eyes

The symptoms of flu can include fever or feeling feverish/chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches and fatigue (tiredness). Cold symptoms are usually milder than the symptoms of flu. People with colds are more likely to have a runny or stuffy nose. Colds generally do not result in serious health problems.

Austin-Travis County recommends the general public use fabric face coverings when conducting essential activities or essential business outside of the home in order to further slow the spread of COVID-19. This follows a national recommendation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in order to help prevent asymptomatic carriers from spreading the virus. Information on tutorials and FAQ can be found here.

People impacted by the new COVID-19 outbreak Orders are invited to visit the following City of Austin COVID-19 webpage for up-to-date information about the Orders and additional services. Community members may contact 3-1-1 with questions about particular services.
Learn more

You can call the City of Austin and/or State of Texas using the following phone numbers 
● 512-974-2000
● 3-1-1 
● 512-978-8775

State of Texas 
● 2‑1‑1

generic.title: Here are some recommended topics to explore:

values.text: Here is a list of emergency shelter providers: ●Casa Marianalla ●Foundation for the Homeless ●Front Steps ●LifeWorks ●The SAFE Alliance -Austin Children's Shelter Campus and Austin Children's Shelter Campus ●Salvation Army- Downtown Shelter and Social Service Center and Downtown Shelter and Social Service Center ●LifeWorks ●The SAFE Alliance-Austin Children's Shelter Campus andDomesticViolence Shelter Campus ●Salvation Army-Downtown Shelter and Social Service Center and Rathgeber Center
During the Coronavirus outbreak most businesses in Austin must close. See what businesses can operate

Public gatherings are not allowed. All businesses and residents must stop on-site activities or work and stay home, except for essential businesses and activities. Everyone must follow social distancing requirements at all times.

All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a single household or dwelling unit is not allowed, except essential activities and essential work or members of a household or dwelling unit.

Caring for a family member, the elderly, minors, dependents, persons with disabilities, or other vulnerable persons in another household is considered an essential activity and is not impacted by the Stay Home - Work Safe order.
For more information: Work Safe Order
Community spread means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.

Austin Public Health has created a flyer for clinics to post in their entrances. A printable version of this flyer is available in the following languages
  • English
  • Spanish
  • Vietnamese
  • Chinese Simplified
  • Chinese Traditional
Please see more information about how you can prepare for COVID as a healthcare provider.

Until further notice, every person who enters the State of Texas as the final destination through an airport from: New York New Jersey Connecticut California Louisiana Washington City of Atlanta, Georgia City of Chicago, Illinois City of Detroit, Michigan City of Miami, Florida And any person entering the State of Texas by roadway from: Louisiana is mandated to self-quarantine for a period of 14 days from the time of entry into Texas or the duration of the person’s presence in Texas, whichever is shorter. The orders to self-quarantine does not apply to people traveling in connection with military service, emergency response, health response, or critical-infrastructure functions, as may be determined by the Texas Division of Emergency Management.
Please email  dsddac\@austintexas.gov. or use the Austin Build + Connect online portal (AB+C ).
Someone with coronavirus would typically have a fever.

The common cold can present with symptoms that are similar to COVID-19 that include fatigue, sore throat, cough and runny nose and possibly a low-grade fever. However, COVID-19 while sometimes presenting with similar symptoms causes high fever, cough and difficulty breathing.

You can protect yourself by taking these steps: - Avoid close contact with people who are sick. - Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands. - Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available. Learn how you can protect yourself and your loved ones.

The City of Austin has taken steps to ensure customers have uninterrupted access to utility services. Immediate assistance is available to all our customers at 1(888) 340-6465. If you are able to do so, you are encouraged to make City of Austin utility payments here or to call Customer Care at 512-494-9400 for service needs. Walk-in utility payment locations are temporarily closed. Learn more about Pay Stations in your location

dialog_nodes.title: Will I continue to get Social Security benefits?

values.text:
You will continue to receive your monthly benefit amount.
If you receive your social security benefit or supplemental security income payment through mail please check please visit the United States Postal Service for their latest statements about COVID-19.
Please visit the Social Security Website for more information.

There is currently no vaccine to prevent coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The best way to prevent illness is to avoid being exposed to this virus.The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).

Common symptoms can vary from person to person. This information is intended to provide personal guidance. Only your doctor can make a complete diagnosis. Seek immediate medical attention for any serious or life threatening health issue.

If it’s a cold virus, you may find yourself close to a tissue box for several days. Most of the time, colds get better on their own in 10 days or less. Colds bring on a nasty mix of symptoms that can really wear you down. They can include:
•	Sore throat 
•	Cough 
•	Headache 
•	Stuffy nose
•	Mucus buildup
•	Sneezing 
•	Fatigue 
•	Swollen sinuses
•	Fever (usually low-grade in adults but higher in children)

dialog_nodes.title: Steps to help prevent the spread of COVID-19

values.text: Fever is one of the symptoms of the coronavirus.

If you do not have insurance or a doctor, but you have symptoms of coronavirus (COVID-19), call the COVID-19 Hotline at 512-978-8775 for guidance. This number is for all Travis County residents with COVID-19 symptoms who don’t have insurance or a doctor. To minimize spread of the virus, please call 512-978-8775 rather than going directly to a clinic, urgent care or emergency department. Stay home and call 512-978-8775 for guidance if you have symptoms such as fever, cough, and/or difficulty breathing, and have been in close contact with a person known to have any of the symptoms above or has been diagnosed with COVID-19. Learn more what you can do if you don't have health insurance

Effective March 23, 2020, DSD will accept Site Plan Correction applications only for changes to active site development permits with current fiscal posting. All corrections must be prepared and submitted as replacement sheets in a digital format. To initiate a Site Plan Correction, please complete and sign the Site Correction Request(PDF) and email the request to dsddac\@austintexas.gov

If your submittal includes large plan files (over 25 MB), please inform staff in your email and they will provide you with further instructions for uploading those files. For properties with site plans that have been completed and closed out, additional modifications or changes will need to be processed through the Site Plan Exemption process.
Please note:  Physical changes to record mylar permit sets are no longer required.

options.label: Latest count of COVID-19 cases in Texas

input.text: what are the number of cases in Austin?

options.label: Austin's Stay Home - Work Safe Order

values.text: If you are experiencing flu-like symptoms, use mobile apps or visit websites that have been set up for COVID-19 response.

Before scheduling an appointment with your healthcare provider or walking into a clinic, urgent care center or hospital it is recommended that you check with your physician’s office directly as they may be offering telehealth appointments with your provider.
For your safety and convenience resources and services are available if you are insured or uninsured.

dialog_nodes.title: What to do if you are sick

values.text:
If you are experiencing symptoms including fever, cough and shortness of breath, call  your doctor or schedule a virtual visit with a medical professional.  Do not go to a doctor’s office, urgent care center or hospital emergency department facility first given heightened threat of coronavirus and the stress on the healthcare system, without calling first.

If you are uninsured and/or don't have a doctor: Call CommUnityCare at 512-978-8775 or 3-1-1 or 2-1-1. They will talk to you over the phone and send you to the appropriate location.

dialog_nodes.title: COA Terms and Condition Opt In

values.text: As part of your everyday prevention actions, clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects while wearing disposable gloves to clean and disinfect. For example: tables, countertops, light switches, doorknobs, and cabinet handles. Learn more about how to disinfect your home

Eviction Resources are available to assist you with legal assistance, emergency grants for rent or utilities, alternate housing, short-term motel vouchers, or placement in a local shelter. Austin Tenants Council provides counseling related to the eviction process, tenant-landlord issues, steps-in to discuss issues, provides workshops, and identifies fair housing issues to resolve or minimize discriminatory housing practices.

Austin ISD Food Services will prepare and provide meals for children under the age of 19 and their parents or caregivers at more than 70 locations while school is closed due to COVID-19 precautions. AISD is working in collaboration with the Texas Department of Agriculture. Click here for more information Can’t find meals in your location? Here is a map to help you find meals in your district.
For pantries and meal assistance please click here. You can also visit the City's website for more information
Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a respiratory illness that is spreading from person to person. Learn more here about Coronavirus

A novel coronavirus is a new coronavirus that has not been previously identified. The virus causing COVID-19 is not the same as the coronaviruses that commonly circulate among humans and cause mild illness, like the common cold. Learn more about Novel Coronavirus

The Austin Disaster Relief Network (ADRN) is partnering with Austin Public Health (APH) and the City's Homeland Security and Emergency Management (HSEM) to collect personal protective equipment from the public.

Effective March 23, 2020, Site Plan Exemption applications must be submitted in a digital format. To initiate a Site Plan Exemption, please complete and sign the Site Plan Exemption Request and email to dsddac\@austintexas.gov
Texas Governor Greg Abbott declares emergency
Full story
Symptoms of the coronavirus (COVID-19) can look similar to the flu and other common ailments. Let's start with the most indicative symptom.

Patients with COVID 19 have reportedly had mild to severe respiratory illness. Symptoms can include: 
•	Fever
•	Cough
•	Shortness of Breath
Having shortness of breath means you're having trouble breathing, in particular taking deep breaths.
So far we have the following cases reported in Austin.
Here are number of cases around the world.
Hope I could help! Bye!
Goodbye!
Hope you have a great day!
The City is maintaining an updated list of resources that includes housing services, where you can go to receive food, etc. View the City of Austin Basic Needs map to locate services

If your employment has been affected by the coronavirus (COVID-19), apply for benefits either online at any time using Unemployment Benefits Services or by calling Texas Workforce Commission’s Tele-Center at 1-800-939-6631 from 8 a.m.- 6 p.m. Central Time Monday through Friday. Click here for more information

There are a lot of unknowns in the world right now. But one thing is certain, your emotional needs are important and if you are worried or upset, there is help. You may be feeling anxiety and worry, sleeping troubles, over or under eating, or sadness and depressed mood.
If you have any of these symptoms, please reach out to: Integral Care 24-Hour Crisis Hotline:  512-472-HELP (4357)
National Alliance for Mental Illness Helpline: 1-800-950-NAMI (6264) or text NAMI to 741741 from Monday-Friday 10:00 a.m.-6:00 p.m. ET
National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255

Hello, I am the City of Austin Bot. 

We know this is a challenging time for all of us, and I'm here to help you find Coronavirus(COVID-19) information and resources.

The City of Austin values your safety and privacy, so here are a couple of rules up front:

1. Please do not share any personal information about yourself or your health with me.

2. For specific medical advice, please contact a local healthcare professional.

generic.title: Do you agree not to share anything personal with me and to talk with your doctor for medical advice?

values.text: Restaurants' common dining areas are not open to the public but drive-through, drive-in, take-away, and delivery are permitted. Remember to always practice social distancing, which means keeping 6 feet of space between you and others at all times. Restaurants' common dining areas will be closed from Tuesday, March 17 until May 1, 2020 unless changed under New Orders, also known as the Stay Home - Work Safe order, designed to slow the spread of COVID-19. See which restaurants are offering takeout or curbside service with Austin Takeout Tracker.Also, Meal on Wheels and More and the City of Austin will be distributing meals for curbside or parking lot pick up, with a limit of 10 meals per person. You must be registered, and they will have a limited number of meals to accept new clients. Learn about meal pick-up dates and locations. Learn more about essential activities and businesses under the order.
Ok ! Let's try it again.

While you are under isolation, you may need to access essential items such as groceries and medications. Several grocery stores are allowing seniors to shop in small numbers before opening up doors to everyone. Please check with your local grocery store for their current hours of operation.

All local Social Security offices will be closed to the public for in-person service starting Tuesday, March 17, 2020. However, we are still able to provide critical services.Please visit the Social Security Website for more information.

Ride Austin has temporarily suspended operations for the safety of our community.Revel has reduced its fleet by 10%.Scoot’s has largely reduced fleet that is primarily made available to help essential workers travel.Zipcar is pausing its operations in Austin for the next month and has removed vehicles from the right of way.

Starting Monday, March 16, all City of Austin playgrounds are closed.
Learn more about Parks and Recreation facilities closures.

All Austin Municipal Court locations will be closed to the public from March 17th-April 16th. We hope to open on April 17th; this date will be subject to change. You can still contact the Court by phone at 512-974-4800 or by emailing court@austintexas.gov to get information and handle their cases.Please note, we are experiencing longer than normal processing times for email and regular mail correspondence.Please visit Municipal Court's website for more information.

The Dewitty Center and Austin Free-Net have changed their services in response to COVID-19. Computer Access Labs remain open until further notice. Digital Literacy Programming is closed from March 16 to March 28. The training calendar has been updated with these changes. Check back for updated information.

As of March 18, U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services(USCIS) temporarily suspended in-person services at its field offices, asylum offices, and Application Support Centers (ASCs) to help slow the spread of Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19). USCIS will provide emergency services for limited situations. To schedule an emergency appointment contact the USCIS Contact Center.

generic.title: For more information on resources for refugees please click below!

values.text: All travel including on-foot, bicycle, scooter, motorcycle, automobile, or public transit, with exception to purposes of essential travel, performing essential activities or going to work in an essential business, government service, or critical infrastructure is prohibited.
Individuals may go on a walk, get exercise, or take a pet outside to go to the bathroom, as long as at least six feet of social distancing is maintained. Learn more: Contain the Spread

Airplanes, taxis, and rideshare programs are considered essential businesses and are able to remain open during this time for people traveling to conduct essential business or critical infrastructure, and caregivers who travel to provide care.See the latest Austin COVID-19 updates for Transportation and Flights
Austin-Bergstrom International Airport remains open. Get up-to-date details on airport travel

We want to go to the library, too! But for public safety, all libraries, including the Austin History Center and Recycled Reads are closed until further notice.   Fortunately, there are lots of online options!

If you are unable to drive and do not have someone that can drive you to pick up groceries, please call 512-972-6240. Certain grocery stores have delivery options available online or by calling directly.

The Animal Shelter is closed to the public until further notice. Check the main City of Austin COVID-19 page for the most updated information on City facility closures.
Bye! Stay Safe.

You can go on a hike. Just keep 6 feet of space or more between you and others at all times, and stay safe out there. In some places the trails are too narrow to maintain 6 feet of space, so proactively communicate with your fellow nature lovers before you get too close. If you notice people getting too close and not following social distancing requirements, find another place to hike. You can call 3-1-1 to report violations.

All in-person services at One Texas Center have been suspended until the March 24, 2020 Order is lifted.
Please visit the Development Services Department COVID-19 page for more information.

Here is a list of other resources for seniors: Family Eldercare has a phone program called Lifetime Connections Without Walls to help people 55 and older deal with social isolation. It provides social and educational sessions and will also have programs on COVID-19.Age of Central Texas has resources on COVID-19 and has made a library of activities and resources online for older adults and caregivers who are quarantined at home. Drive a Senior provides free rides for seniors who sign up their service and schedule their rides ahead of time.Please contact the Drive a Senior partner serving your area:Aging Services Council of Central Texas lists more services and volunteer opportunities on its website. Call them at 512-593-2269.Meals on Wheels Central Texas delivers hot, nutritious meals to the elderly, disabled, and homebound in the Greater Austin area. Contact Meals on Wheels at (512) 476-6325.
CapMetro is implementing temporary changes to their services to help you.

Colleges and universities have moved their classes online. Please contact your school for further details.

By order of the Mayor of Austin, until May 1, 2020, any public or private gatherings of more than 10 people in a single room or space is prohibited.
This order does not apply to critical infrastructure such as airports, transit facilities, government buildings, schools, grocery stores, pharmacies, hospitals and medical facilities.
Read the full ordinance here
For more specific information around closures, please state the nature of the business you are asking about(restaurants, parks, libraries, etc.).

It’s still fine to leave your home to buy groceries, go for a run, walk the dog, or ride your bike. When biking to essential activities, maintain 6+ feet from others and wash your hands after each trip.  Austin Bcycle is offering Austin BCyle to anyone making essential trips during the Stay Home - Work Safe Order and has increased the frequency of cleaning and disinfecting all Bcycle bikes and stations. Bird has reduced the majority of its fleet as of March 27 except a small fleet of vehicles so that essential workers can use them for travel. Lyft is prioritizing scooter deployment near local hospitals to facilitate essential trips by healthcare workers.The following companies have paused their operations and removed all devices from the right of way until further notice. They still have staff available to respond to Austin 3-1-1 requests. Lime, as of March 17 Wheels, as of March 19 Spin, as of March 26 JUMP, as of March 27
Let's get you going.

Public parks are open, but most Parks and Recreation facilities are closed starting Monday, March 16th. As long as you keep 6 feet of space or more between you and others at all times, enjoy the parks and trails that are open.

generic.title: For details on which park facilities will be closed please click here:

values.text: Two trails are closed for now. Shoal Creek Trail (24th to 29th of Lamar) is closed until further notice due to damage by landslide. Walnut Creek Trail is closed at the US 183 crossing January 13 to late March 2020. Use the detour to cross the highway. Learn more about Parks and Recreation facilities closures.

If your pharmacy does not have a delivery option, check if they have a drive-thru location. You may also call the pharmacy and find out if they can transfer your refill to another location for a one-time pick-up.
